superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter m c
ma for the interrogative maA immediately following a prep.: see maA in the S, K; and UilaI last sentence. ― -b2- mi for mino: see an ex., from a poet, voce rubRa. ― -b3- mu QllRehi &c.: see Oayomunu AllRehi. ― -b4- mR for OumR: see the latter.

maA c
maA when following kulR or UinRa or Oayona or OaIR, if having the signification of AlRaciI, is written separately. (El-Hareeree, in De Sacy's Anthol. Gram. Ar., p. 67 of the Ar. text.) ― -b2- maA added to certain adverbial nouns is not merely redundant, but gives to them a conditional and general signification; as in OayonamaA Wherever; and HayovumaA Wherever, and whenever; &c.: see Kur, ii. 143, 145, &c.: and see De Sacy's Gram., i. 537 and 538. ― -b3- maA While; as in maA dumotu HayRFA: and as much as; see Kur, lxiv. 16. ― -b4- bimaA Because bimaA kaAnuwA yafosuquwna Because they did transgress; or for that they did transgress. (Kur.) ― -b5- UinRaka maA waxayorFA, for maEa xayorK. See xayorN. ― -b6- maA is also added to a noun to denote the littleness of that which is signified by the noun; as in OarabN mRaA Some little want. (IAth in TA, art. Arb.) ― -b7- maA in OamRaA and UimRaA (of which latter UimRaA laA is an instance) I have mentioned in arts. OamRaA and UimRaA. ― -b8- baAligFA maA balaga: see balaga. ― -b9- maA Oanota [What art thou?] means what are thy qualities, or attributes? (Har, p. 155.) maA rabRu AlEaAlamiyna, in the Kur, xxvi. 22, means OaIRN XaIoCK huwa. (Jel.) See also an ex. voce faIR. ― -b10- maA laka signifies OaIRu XaIoCK vabata laka (IbrD) and may be rendered What aileth thee? ― -b11- XaIoCN mRaA Some particular thing: something. (See Uiyhi.) Also, Any particular thing? (IbrD.) See an ex. cited voce SabaAHN. ― -b12- fatFI mRaA fulaAnN An excellent youth is such a one. (IbrD.) See Kull, p. 336. See also Bd, middle p. 42. ― -b13- maA is sometimes put for maA daAma, maA daAmuwA, and the like; i. e. As long as: see an ex. voce kaAZRa, and AltRuroku, and jalRa. ― -b14- AlXRakolu UilaI AlTRuwli maA huwa The form inclines somewhat to length; agreeably with a rendering voce EuqorN: see De Sacy's Gr., sec. ed., i. 543 and 539: see also XaIoCN mRaA above: in the Kur xxxviii. 23, mA is redundant, (Bd,) denoting vagueness and wonder, (Ksh, Bd,) or a corroborative of fewness: (Jel:) it means somewhat whether great or little in degree or importance. ＝ -A2- maA, the negative particle, followed by a pret., often requires the latter to be rendered in English by the preterperfect: ex. maA raOayotuhu muco yawomaAn I have not seen him for two days. See De Sacy's Anthol. Gram. Ar., p. 253.

maOoqN c
maOoqN and muWoqN and maOoqK: see maOwFI.

maOaqapN c
maOaqapN A sobbing; i. e. an affection like what is termed fuwaAq, as though it were breath heaved from the chest, on an occasion of weeping, and of being choked with weeping. (S, K.)

1 maOanahumo c
1. maOanahumo He sustained them; bore the burden of, or undertook, their maintenance; he maintained them. (S, K, arts. mOn and mwn.) ― -b2- maOana Alqawoma and maORanahumo↓ He maintained, or sustained, the people, or party. (M.)

2 maARa^a
2: see 1.

maOonapN c
maOonapN of the belly: see jaOobapN. ― -b2- AlmaOonataAni of the hump of a camel: see qaHadapN.

muWonapN c
muWonapN i. q. quwotN [Food, &c.]; (M;) a dial. var. of maWuwnapN↓ (q. v.); as also muwnapN: pl. muWanN. (Msb.)

maYinRapN c
maYinRapN: see art. An, where will be found the explanations of this word given in the S and K in art. mOn.

maWwnapN c
maWwnapN A weight, or burden. (Mgh, Msb.) See mivoqaAlN. ― -b2- Trouble, molestation, or embarrassment; as also muWonapN↓: pl. of the former maWuwnaAtN; and of the latter muWanN. (MA.) ― -b3- The requisite means of subsistence. (KL.) ― -b4- maWuwnapu AljimaAEi: see zaAfinapN: it seems to mean the pudendum muliebre considered as the means of jimaAE.

maAhiyRapN c
maAhiyRapN [The quiddity, or essence, or substance, of a thing;] that whereby a thing is what it is. (KT.) See also HaqiyqapN, and jawoharN, and caAtiyRapN, and maEonFI.

miYiynN c
miYiynN: see siniynN, voce sanapN, in art. snh.

1 maOaI c
1. maOaI (like maACa) It (a cat) mewed. (TA, voce maACa, art. mwO.)

1 mataEa AlnRahaAru c
1. mataEa AlnRahaAru The day became advanced, the sun being high, (S, K,) before the declining of the sun from the meridian. (K.). matRaEahu He (God) made him to live. (Bd in xi. 3.) ― -b2- See malRA. ― -b3- matRaEahaA He gave her a gift after divorce. (K.) And matRahaA bikacaA He gave her (a divorced wife) such a thing. (Msb.)

5 tamatRaEa bihi c
5. tamatRaEa bihi and AisotamotaEa↓ and AimotataEa↓ are syn., signifying AinotafaEa bihi zamaAnFA TawiylFA; (Ham, p. ???;) [He benefited, or profited by it; had the benefit, use, or enjoyment, of it; he enjoyed it; accord. to the above authority, for a long time; but this restriction is not always meant.] You say. AisotamotaEotu biQSoTibaAHi xamorK [I enjoyed the drinking a morning-draught of wine]: and biAlUiSogaMCi UilaI OagaAniI jaAriyapK [the listening to the songs of a girl].
(Mo'allakát, p. 169.) ― -b2- tamatRaEa He became provided with mataAE, or utensils and furniture for the house, or tent. (TA, voce tabatRata, q. v.) ― -b3- tamatRaEa i. q. EaAXa. (Bd, Jel, xi. 68.) ― -b4- tamatRaEa bihi generally signifies He enjoyed it: (MA:) so in many cases in the Kur, &c.

8 UimotataEa
8: see 5.

10 AisotamotaEa bikacaA c
10. AisotamotaEa bikacaA, and tamatRaEa↓, He benefited or profited by such a thing. (Msb.) ― -b2- See 5. ― -b3- musotamotuEN: see malobasN.

mutoEapN c
mutoEapN Enjoyment; a subst. in the sense of tamatRuEN; (S, Msb, K;) syn. naEomapN. (Jel, xlvi. 26.) See an ex., in a verse of Lebeed, voce faroTN. ― -b2- mutoEapN A gift to a divorced wife. (Msb, K.) See mataAEN. ― -b3- mtEp AlDRuHaI [i. e. mutoEap?] i. q. OawRaluhaA. (TA voce fiyqap, in art. fwq.)

mataAEN c
mataAEN Anything useful or advantageous; as goods: such as the utensils and furniture of a house or tent, or household-goods: any utensils, or apparatus: chattels: a commodity, and commodities; (Mgh, &c.;) generally best rendered goods, chattels, household-goods or chattels, or utensils and furniture. ― -b2- AlmataAEu [signifies (tropical:) Alfaroju;] a woman's pudendum: (TA:) [see mutawahRijapN, in art. whj: and] the penis. (Mgh.) ― -b3- mataAEN also applies to Food, the necessaries of life: see two exs. voce HafafN. ― -b4- mataAEN for a divorced wife, A provision of necessaries, such as food and clothing and household-utensils or furniture: see EarofN, and Bd in ii. 242: i. q. tamotiyEN. (Bd in ii. 237.) ― -b5- mataAEN i. q. maA yutamatRaEu bihi, and AlAisotimotaAEu; (Jel in iv. 79;) generally best rendered Enjoyment, in the Kur iv. 79 and ix. 38 and similar cases. See mutoEapN.

2 matRanahu c
2. matRanahu, inf. n. tamutiynN, He made it, or rendered it, strong, stout, form, or hard. (TA.) ― -b2- matRana He seasoned a skin with rob, or inspissated juice (rubR). (K.)

matonu AlZRahori c
matonu AlZRahori is The erector spinæ muscle, which consists of the sacro-lumbalis and longissimus dorsi and spinalis dorsi. The matonN is The back: (M, Msb:) or, as also matonapN↓, (M,) or matonaAni, (T,) two portions of firmly-bound flesh between which is the back-bone, [or that confine the back-bone,] rendered firm by being tied (maEoluwbataAni) with, or by, Eaqab [or sinews,] (T, M,) or the matonataAni are the two sides of the back. (M.) ― -b2- matonaA AlZahori The two portions of flesh and sinew next the back-bone, on each side. (S.) ― -b3- matonN [The broad side, or the middle of the broad side, of the blade, of a sword;] the part in the middle of which is the [ridge called] Eamuwd, (En-Nadr, in L, voce EamuwdN,) or the part in which is the [ridge called] XuTobap, (K, voce safosaqapN,) and XaTiybap, and Eamuwd: (K, voce EamuwdN:) or the ridge [itself] (Eayor) rising in the middle of a sword. (T.) ― -b4- matonN The hard and outer or apparent part of anything: pl. mutuwnN and mitaAnN. (M.) ― -b5- matonN The middle of a bow, and of a spear. (Munjid of Kr.) ― -b6- matonu Oucuni Alfarasi: see EayorN. ― -b7- matonN The part between two poles of a bayot, or tent. (AZ in TA, art. rbE.) ― -b8- matonN Elevated, and level, or plain, ground: (M:) or hard and elevated ground. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b9- matonu Alfarasi One of the four bright stars in Pegasus, that (a) at the extremity of the neck: see Alfarogu. ― -b10- matonN i. q. HadiyvN and xabarN and OavarN, A tradition of Mohammad, or of another, namely a companion of Mohammad, &c. (IbrD.)

matonapN c
matonapN: see matonN.

matiynN c
matiynN Strong; stout; firm; hard. (S, K, Msb.) [Well seasoned. Possessing any quality in a strong degree.]

Oamotanu HalaAwapF c
Oamotanu HalaAwapF, i. q. OaXadRu HalaAwapF, More sweet. (TA, voce HamotN.)

timotaAnN c
timotaAnN: see tamotiynN.

tamotiynN c
tamotiynN (a subst., properly speaking, like talobiybN, q. v.) and timotaAnN↓ The threads, or strings, of tents. (K.)

mataI c
mataI signifies When? and when used to denote a condition: see OanRaI and Oayona. ― -b2- HatRaI mataI Until when? how long? and also until the time when. See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 382.

1 mavala c
1. mavala aor.
mavula
, inf. n. muvuwlN; (S, M, K, &c.;) and mavula; (M, K;) He stood erect; (S, M, K, &c.;) bayona yadayohi before him. (S, &c.) ― -b2- mavala bihi, inf. n. muvolapN, He mutilated him; castrated him; namely, a sheep or goat. (TA in art. djn, from a trad.)

2 mavRala c
2. mavRala: see a verse of Kutheiyir in art. rwd, conj. 4. ― -b2- mavRalahu: see XabRahahu.

3 maAvalahu c
3. maAvalahu i. q. XaAbahahu. (TA.)

4 Oamovalahu c
4. Oamovalahu He set it up: from mavala “ he stood erect. ” ― -b2- He set up a butt or mark: see an ex. voce garaDN.

5 tamavRala bikacaA c
5. tamavRala bikacaA [He affected to be like, or imitated, such a thing;] i. q. taXabRaha bihi. (TA, art. Xbh.) ― -b2- tamavRala Albayota and [more commonly] biAlbayoti He used, or applied, the verse as a proverb, or proverbially. (MA.) ― -b3- See taXabRaha.

6 tamaAvala c
6. tamaAvala He became nearly in a sound, or healthy, state; or near to convalescence: (K:) or he became more like the sound, or healthy, than the unsound, or unhealthy, who is suffering from a chronic and pervading disease; (TA;) or so tmAvl liloburoCi. (M.) Said also of a wound: (T, S in art. dml:) and of a disease; like OaXokala. (TA, art. Xkl.) ― -b2- tamaAvalaA i. q. taXaAbahaA. (M, K in art. swI.)

8 Aimotavala Oamorahu c
8. Aimotavala Oamorahu He followed his command, order, bidding, or injunction; did like as he commanded, ordered, &c.; (Mgh;) he obeyed his command, order, &c. (Msb.)

mivolN c
mivolN A like; a similar person or thing; match; fellow; an analogue. (K, &c.) See nidRN and voce badalN. ― -b2- A likeness, resemblance, or semblance; see XabahN. ― -b3- An equivalent; a requital. ― -b4- mivola, used as a denotative of state, means Like. Ex. marRa mivola Albaroqi He passed like the lightning. See an ex. in the Kur li. 23; and another, from Sakhr-el-Gheí, voce faroDN.

mavalN c
mavalN i. q. SifapN [as meaning A description, condition, state, case, &c.]; (S, K, &c.;) or waSofN [meaning the same]: (Msb:) or this is a mistake: (Mbr, AAF, TA:) or it may be a tropical signification: (MF, TA:) for in the language of the Arabs it means a description by way of comparison: (AAF, TA:) you say mvl zyd mvl flAn [The description of Zeyd, by way of comparison, or the condition, &c., is that of such a one]: it is from AlmivAalu and AlHacowu: (Mbr, TA:) it is metaphorically applied to a condition, state, or case, that is important, strange, or wonderful. (Ksh, Bd in ii. 16.) The phrase here given is more literally, and better, rendered, The similitude of Zeyd is the similitude, or is that, of such a one; for a similitude is a description by way of comparison. ― -b2- You say also, jaEalahu mavalFA likacaA [He made it (an expression or the like) to be descriptive, by way of comparison, of such a thing]. (TA passim.) [And mavalN likacaA means An expression denoting, by way of similitude, such a thing.] ― -b3- EalaI Almavali As indicative of resemblance to something. ― -b4- See badalN.

mivaAlN c
mivaAlN Quality, made, manner, fashion, and form; (Msb;) a model according to which another thing is made or proportioned; a pattern, (miqodaArN) by which a thing is measured, proportioned, or cut out: (T:) an example of a class
of words, of a rule, &c. ― -b2- mino gayori saboqi mivAalK [Without there having been any precedent]. (Msb in art. qrH, &c.) ― -b3- [A bed:] banAatu AlmivaAli The daughters of the bed; meaning women. (T in art. bnI.)

jawozu maAvilK c
jawozu maAvilK: see jawozN.

tamaAviylu c
tamaAviylu, in the following hemistich of Ibn-Ahmar,
tamaAviylu qiroTaAsK EalaI habohabiyRapK
signifies kutubN yakotubuwnahaA. (L, in TA, voce habohabiIRN, as signifying a “ light, or active, ” camel.)

1 majara c
1. majara, app. an imitative sequent to fajara. See daEira.

1 majalato yaduhu c
1. majalato yaduhu His hand became blistered, or vesicated, by much work. (Mgh.)

majomajapN c
majomajapN: see jamojama and HajoHaja.

1 majana c
1. majana He cared not for what he did (S. Mgh, K *) nor for what was said to him. (Mgh, K. *) The epithet is maAjinN. (S, Mgh, K.)

EuqobapN majuwnN c
EuqobapN majuwnN [A stage of a journey, or a march or journey from one halting-place to another,] that is far, or distant, or long. (ISk in TA, voce baAsiTapN: but it is not quite clear in my copy of the TA whether it be majuwnN or hajuwnN.)

majRaAnN c
majRaAnN The gift of a thing without price. (IF, Msb.) ― -b2- faEalotuhu majRaAnFA I did it without compensation. (Msb.) hecaA AlXRaIoCu lahu majRaAnFA This thing is for him without an equivalent. (El-Farábee, Msb.)

maAjinN c
maAjinN: see 1.

1 majonaquwA mjnqwA
1. majonaquwA: see art. jnq.

maHotN c
maHotN and maHotapN: see OabotN.

1 maHaqa c
1. maHaqa, aor.
maHaqa
, inf. n. maHoqN, He rendered a thing deficient, and deprived it of its blessing, or increase: or [he annihilated, annulled, or obliterated, it;] he did away with it wholly, so that no trace thereof remained. (Msb.) ― -b2- OaEomadu mino kayolK muHiRqa↓, or muHiqa: see Eamada.

2 maHRaqa
2: see 1.

layaAliI AlmuHaAqi c
layaAliI AlmuHaAqi: see daOodaMCN and AldRaEojaMCu.

4 OamoHalati AlnRujuwmu c
4. OamoHalati AlnRujuwmu The stars set aurorally and brought no rain. (S, K * in art. xwI.)

5 tamaHRalotu maAlFA bigayori vamanK c
5. tamaHRalotu maAlFA bigayori vamanK I laboured to acquire property without price: (Msb:) or, accord. to Az, tamaHRala maAlFA means he laboured, and exercised art or management, in seeking [to acquire] property. (TA.) See also taEalRava.

maHolN c
maHolN Drought, or suspension of rain, (S, K, Msb in art. jdb,) and dryness of the earth (S, Msb ubi suprà) depriving it of herbage; (S, TA;) and i. q. jadobN. (K.)

maHaAlapN mHAl mHAlh mHAlp mHl
maHaAlapN: see art. Hwl; and see also fawohaMCu voce Oafowahu, and fawoqaMCu voce Oafowaqu, and qabRN.

labanN mumaHRalN c
labanN mumaHRalN Sour milk upon which much fresh is milked: see qaAriSN.

mutamaAHilN c
mutamaAHilN: see radaAHN.

miHonapN c
miHonapN A trial, (S, Msb, K,) or trying affliction: (S:) pl. miHanN. (Msb.)

maHuwnapN mHA mHwnh mHwnp
maHuwnapN (not muHuwnapN): see art. Hyn.

1 maHaAhu c
1. maHaAhu He effaced, erased, rased, obliterated, or cancelled, it; removed, or did away with, its impression or trace. (K.) ― -b2- maHati AlrRiyHu Eanohu AlOasoqaAma waAldRunuwba The wind made to pass away, or dispelled, the clouds. (TA.) ― -b3- maHaA AlSRuboHu AllRayola Daybreak dispelled the night. (TA.) ― -b4- maHaAQllRehu Eanohu AlOasoqaAma waAldRunuwba [God removed from him diseases and sins; as though He cancelled them]. (Msb in art. Efw.) ― -b5- AlUiHosaAnu yamoHuw AlUisaMCapa Beneficence effaces, obliterates, or cancels, evil conduct. (TA)

mayodaAnN c
mayodaAnN: see art. myd.

huwa Qbonu madiynatihaA c
huwa Qbonu madiynatihaA, said of a skilful guide: see bajodapN.

1 madaha c
1. madaha: see madaHa.

6 tamaAdaI fiI gayRihi c
6. tamaAdaI fiI gayRihi He persevered in his error. (Msb.)

madFI c
madFI The utmost extent, term, limit, or reach, of a thing; syn. gaAyapN: (S, Msb, K:) an extent, a distance; a space, an interval; syn. masaAfapN. [meaning a space that is, or that is to be, traversed] and hence used in the sense before explained because extending to a gAyp: (Z, in the Fáïk, quoted in the TA:) a goal. (The Lexicons passim.)

mudoyapN c
mudoyapN A butcher's knife. (Mgh.) See sikRiynN.

macuwqN c
macuwqN Milk mixed with much water. (TA in art. fDx.)

mamocuwqu AlnRiqoIi c
mamocuwqu AlnRiqoIi [Having diluted marrow]; applied to a soft, or flabby, camel. (O, K in art. rk.) ― -b2- EayoXN mamocuwqN (assumed tropical:) A turbid life. (TA in art. smr.)

Q. 4 AimocaqarRati AlUibilu c
Q. 4. AimocaqarRati AlUibilu The camels became dispersed. (TA in art. SEr.)

4 OamocaI c
4. OamocaI Humorem tenuem e pene emisit vir propter lusum amatorium rel osculum. (Msb, &c.)

macoIN c
macoIN Humor tenuis qui propter lusum amatorium vel osculum e pene virili effluit: a discharge of a thin humour from the cakar, occasioned by amorous toying or by kissing: [app the prostatic fluid, a discharge from the prostate gland.] (S, Msb, &c.)

macRaACN c
macRaACN app., Is qui multum passus est seminis effluxum ex contactu feminæ aut osculo. See mazokuwtN. See also OamocaI.

maAciIRN c
maAciIRN Honey: (K:) or white honey: (S, M:) or fine, or thin, white honey. (AA, TA.)

marRN c
marRN A spade; [so in the present day;] syn. misoHaApN; (M, K;) with which one works in land of seed-produce: (M and K, voce baAlN:) or the handle thereof: (M, K;) and in like manner, of the miHoraAv [app. here meaning fire-shovel]: (M:) [see sixRiynN] the thing with which one works in earth, or mud. (Sgh, TA.)

murayoraMCu c
murayoraMCu An anæsthetic herb: see sakarapN.

marozN c
marozN [an inf. n.] i. q. EayobN; as also lamozN. (Fr in TA, art. lmz.)

maraAsapN c
maraAsapN [A wooden rake or harrow:] i. q. malAasapN. (TA, art. SlE.)

miriToraATN c
miriToraATN [A sweet food:] i. q. faAluwcN; as also siriToraATN. (TA in art. zE.)

1 maruEa c
1. maruEa and OamoraEa↓ It (a valley) abounded with herbage. (S, Msb, K.)

4 OamoraEa
4: see 1.

muraEN c
muraEN, the bird so called: see an ex. voce bulaEN.

2 marRaga c
2. marRaga He rolled, or turned over, a beast of carriage, in the dust. (K.) ― -b2- marRaga He smeared, seasoned, imbued, or soaked, a mess of variydi, with grease, or gravy, or dripping; i. q. rawRaga, and dasRama, and sagobala. (TA in art. rwg.)

3 maAragahu c
3. maAragahu [He rolled with him upon the ground, or in the dust]; said of a man after his wrestling with another. (TA in art. rsg.) See 3, in that art.

8 Aimotaraqa c
8. Aimotaraqa He drew a sword from its scabbard. (TA, voce Aihotalaba; and voce AiEotaqRa.)

maroqu AlUihaAbi c
maroqu AlUihaAbi The burying of the skin, or hide, in the earth, so that its hair may be removed, and it may become ready for tanning. (K, * TA in art. Afq.) See also falaqa.

maraqN c
maraqN in grapes: see sukRarN. ― -b2- maraqN Broth; gravy-soup; and any decoction.

sahomN maAriqN c
sahomN maAriqN An arrow of which the whole has passed through the animal at which it is shot. (A, art. mrd.) See SaAridN, and mugotalimu.

murRiyqN c
murRiyqN: see durRiIoCN. ― -b2- murRayoq in the K is a mistake for murRiyq. (TA.) See also EiulRiyRahN, in art. Elw, in which murRiyqapN is mentioned as the n. un.

entry.hi: A kind of small lantern in the roof of a chamber, for the admission of air, generally octagonal, the sides of wooden lattice-work, and the top a cupola; a sky-light; any kind of window or aperture in a roof.

superEntry.entry:
1 marana c
1. marana It was, or became smooth, (S, M, K,) with a degree of hardness. (M, K.) Said of a camel's foot: see OasoHaqa. ― -b2- marana EalaI XaIoCK He became accustomed, habituated, or inured, to a thing. (K.)

2 marRanahu c
2. marRanahu He made it soft, or smooth, layRin. (Msb.)

maArinN c
maArinN The [soft, or cartilagenous] part of the nose, beneath, or exclusive of, the bone. (Zj, in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ” and the like is said in the S and Msb, and partially in the K.)

1 AlrRiyHu tamoriI AlsRaHaAba c
1. AlrRiyHu tamoriI AlsRaHaAba and tamotariyhi↓ The wind draws forth the clouds. (M, TA.) See an ex. in a verse cited voce EazolaMCu.

3 maAraAhu c
3. maAraAhu, inf. n. mumaAraApN and miraMCN, i. q. jaAdalahu; (S, K; *) He disputed with him, or did so obstinately, &c.: (TA:) it is only in opposing [what has been said; not in commencing a disputation]. (Msb.)

6 AltRamaAriI c
6. AltRamaAriI The disputing, or contending, together. (TA.) You say, humaA yatamaArayaAni biAlXRiEori [They two dispute, or contend, together, with verses or poetry]. (TA in art. bdh.)

8 AimotraI c
8. AimotraI He doubted, bh of it. (Kur, xliii. 61.) ― -b2- See 1.

10 Aisotamorati AlUibilu AlmHamoDa c
10. Aisotamorati AlUibilu AlmHamoDa for AisotamoraOatohu: see 1 in art. Edn.

marowN c
marowN A certain plant: see xaAfuwrN, and HabaqN, and faAxuwrN.

maziyrN c
maziyrN Strong-hearted. (S.) So I have rendered the fem. (with p) in explaining balohaMCu: it seems there to mean bold.

2 mazRaqa c
2. mazRaqa (assumed tropical:) He scattered, or dispersed. (Kur, xxxiv, 18; and Expos. of the Jeláleyn.) ― -b2- [marRaqa, used tropically, may sometimes be rendered (assumed tropical:) He mangled, rent much, or dissundered; but more generally, (assumed tropical:) he, or it, shattered, disorganized, or dissipated; or (assumed tropical:) he, or it, marred, or impaired; being opposed to OaSolaHa, or to raqaEa or raqRaEa, in the sense of OaSolaHa, as in an ex. cited voce raqaEa; sometimes several of these renderings will be found to be appropriate in a single instance. You say, mazRaqa EiroDahu (assumed tropical:) He mangled, rent, or shattered, or marred, his honour, or reputation. And mazRaqa Eaqolahu, and raOoyahu, and Oamorahu, (assumed tropical:) It shattered, or disorganized or dissipated, or it marred or impaired, his intellect, and his judgment, and his state of affairs or circumstances.] ― -b3- mazRaiqahu He rent it, or tore it, much; or in several, or many, places. mangled, or dissundered, it; and cut it much; &c. (TA.)

5 tamazRaqa Ealayohi Eaqoluhu c
5. tamazRaqa Ealayohi Eaqoluhu (assumed tropical:) [His intellect became shattered, or dissipated, or impaired]. (TA in art. raqaEa.) And tamazRaqa Ealayohi raOoyuhu waOamoruhu (assumed tropical:) [His judgment, and his state of affairs or circumstances, became shattered, disorganized, dissipated, marred, or impaired. (A and TA in art. rqE.) See mazRaqa, of which tamazRaqa is quasi-pass. ― -b2- tamazRaquwA (assumed tropical:) They became scattered, or dispersed. (TA.) ― -b3- tamazRaqa EiroDuhu (assumed tropical:) His honour, or reputation, became mangled, rent, or shattered, or marred.

mazoqN c
mazoqN The rending, tearing, or slitting, a garment and the like. (JK.)

mizoqapN c
mizoqapN A piece torn off of a garment (S, K *) &c. (K.)

mizaAqN c
mizaAqN [A she-camel] whose skin almost becomes rent in pieces by reason of her swiftness. (O in art. Ensq.)

muzonN c
muzonN Clouds (K, and Ham, p. 564) of any kind: (Ham, ibid:) or white clouds: (S, K, and Ham, p. 53:) or clouds containing water. (K.)

Uibonu maAzinK c
Uibonu maAzinK The ant. (TA in art. bnI.)

2 tamoziyapN c
2. tamoziyapN The praising, or eulogizing [another]. (K, TA.) You say, mazRayotuhu Ealayohi, syn. faDRalotuhu. (IAar, TA.)

5 tamazRayota EalayonaA c
5. tamazRayota EalayonaA Thou thoughtest, or hast thought, thyself superior to us in excellence: and so tafaDRalota. (TA.)

6 tamaAzawoA c
6. tamaAzawoA i. q. tafaADaluwA. (TA.)

maziyRapN c
maziyRapN An excellent quality; an excellence. (S, Msb, K.)

1 yumosiku AlrRamaqa c
1. yumosiku AlrRamaqa: see art. rmq.

2 masRaka biAlnRaAri c
2. masRaka biAlnRaAri: see vqRb.

4 Oamosaka c
4. Oamosaka He retained; he withheld. (Msb.) ― -b2- He maintained: he was tenacious, or niggardly. ― -b3- He, or it, held fast a thing: and arrested it. ― -b4- Oamosakahu He held, retained, detained,
restrained, stayed, confined, imprisoned, or withheld, him. (K.) ― -b5- Oamosaka Eani AlOamori He held, refrained, or abstained, from the thing. (Msb.) ― -b6- Oamosakahu He grasped it, clutched it, laid hold upon it; or seized it, (qabaDa Ealayohi) biyadihi with his hand: (Msb:) or he took it; or took it with his hand, (Oaxacahu,) namely, a rope, &c.: (Mgh:) or he held, or clung, to it: (TA:) [as also bihi tamaska↓]. Also, Oamosaka bihi signifies [the same; or] he laid hold upon, or seized, somewhat of his body, or what might detain him, as an arm or a hand, or a garment, and the like: but Oamosaqahu may signify he withheld him, or restrained him, from acting according to his own free will. (Mugh, art. bi.) ― -b7- Oamosaka baTonahu [It bound, or confined, his belly (or bowels)]: said of medicine. (S, O, Msb, K; all in art. Eql.) ― -b8- AlUimosaAk, in relation to taHojiyl: see an unusual application of it in art. Tlq, conj. 4.

5 tamasRaka
5: see 4 and 8. ― -b2- tamasRaka biHabolihi He held fast by his covenant: see OaEoSama.

6 tamaAsaka c
6. tamaAsaka He withheld, or restrained, himself: (PS:) he was able, or powerful; as also tamaAlaka, q. v. (KL.) ― -b2- maA tamaAsaka Oano faEala kacaA He could not restrain himself from doing so; syn. maA tamaAlka. (S.) ― -b3- tamaAsaka It held together. ― -b4- UinRahu lacuw tamaAsukK (assumed tropical:) Verily he possesses intelligence. (TA.) And maAbihi tamaAsukN (tropical:) There is no good in him. (TA.) See musokapN.

8 Aimotasaka bihi c
8. Aimotasaka bihi He clutched, or griped, him, or it; i. q. bihi tamasRaka↓. (MA.)

10 Aisotamosaka AlbaTonu c
10. Aisotamosaka AlbaTonu [The belly (or bowels) became bound, or confined]. (TA in art. Eql.) ― -b2- Aisotamosaka bihi [sometimes] He sought to lay hold upon it. (Bd, in ii. 257.) ― -b3- Aisotamosaka: see an ex. voce SiroEapN.

misokN c
misokN [Musk: it is obtained from the muskdeer, moschus moschiferus; being found in the male animal, in a vesicle near the navel and prepuce.] It is masc. and fem. (IAmb, TA voce cakiIRN.)

masakN c
masakN Tortoise-shell; syn. cabolN: (K:) bracelets made of tortoise-shell (cabolN), or of EAj [ivory]: (S, Msb:) bracelets and anklets made of horn and of EAj: n. un. with musokapN. (K.)

musokapN c
musokapN Intelligence: (Msb:) or full intelligence, (K, TA,) and judgment; judgment and intel-ligence to which one has recourse; as also musokN, not masiykN↓, as in the K; (TA;) i. q. tamaAsukN. (Mgh.) You say, layosa lahu musokapN He has no intel-ligence. (Msb.) ― -b2- layosa bihi musokapN He has no strength. (Msb.)

musokaAnN c
musokaAnN: see art. skn.

misaAkN c
misaAkN or masaAkN A kind of needles: see midaAdN.

masiykN c
masiykN: see musokapN.

masRaAkAtN c
masRaAkAtN [in the CK, art. rwD, written musRAkAt,] Places, in land, or in the ground, to which the rain-water flows, and which retain it. (TA.) See DaAbiTapN.

mumosakN c
mumosakN, said of a horse, white on both fore and kind leg on the same side: see muHajRalN.

mutamaAsikN c
mutamaAsikN Compact in the limbs, (TA in art. bdn,) or flesh. (TA in this art.)

masalN c
masalN: see masiylN, in art. syl.

2 masRaAhu bikacaA c
2. masRaAhu bikacaA He came to him in the evening with such a thing. (TA, voce SabRaHa.)

4 OamosaI c
4. OamosaI He entered upon the masaMC. (Msb.) ― -b2- OamosaI as syn. with SaAra: see an ex. voce naXaTa, in a verse of Himyán, and another voce EasaI.

Oanayotuhu limuisoIi xaAmisapK c
Oanayotuhu limuisoIi xaAmisapK: see SuboHN.

masaMCN c
masaMCN Afternoon, counted from noon to sunset: (Az, IKoot, Mgh, Msb, TA:) or, accord. to some, to midnight: (TA:) contr. of SabaAH: (S, K, Msb, &c.:) and evening, after sunset. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Oatayotuhu caA masaMCK [I came to him in the evening]. (IAar, TA, art. SbH.) See SabaAHN. ― -b3- Oatayotupu SabaAHFA masaMCF: see SabaAHN.

OamosiyRapN c
OamosiyRapN: see OuSobuwHap.

mamosFI c
mamosFI a name for the masaMC; and the time thereof; and the place thereof; like as maSobaHN is a name for the SabaAH; and the time thereof; and the place thereof. (Marg. note in a copy of the S, in art. SbH.)

musotamosakN c
musotamosakN A place, or thing, to lay hold of: see maEaDRN.

R. Q. 2 tamaXomaXati AlUibilu c
R. Q. 2. tamaXomaXati AlUibilu The camels became dispersed. (TA in art. SEr.)

1 maXaqa AlxaTRa c
1. maXaqa AlxaTRa He elongated the handwriting: or was quick in it. (M.)

2 tamoXiyqN c
2. tamoXiyqN The act of lacerating much: see an ex. voce daHiyqN.

kitaAbu maXoqK c
kitaAbu maXoqK Writing with spaces, or gaps, and with elongated letters; (JK;) [or quick, or hasty, writing; (see maXaqa;)] contr. of kitaAbu AltRaHaAsiyni. (K in art. Hsn.)

muXaAqapN c
muXaAqapN [the hards, or hurds, of flax or hemp and any similar coarse fibres: (see salabN:) or tow; i. e.] what falls from the combing of hair and flax and the like: (S, K:) or what is long: or not cleared: (K:) or what remains, of flax, after combing, that is, after it has been drawn through the mimoXaqap↓, [or heckle,] which is a thing like a comb, whereby the best becomes cleared, the broken particles and integuments, which constitute the muXaAqap, remaining. (Mgh.)

muXRaqN c
muXRaqN A certain sea-fish. (K, voce mudRajN: in the CK, muXaqRN.)

mimoXaqapN c
mimoXaqapN: see muXaAqahN.

mamoXuwqN c
mamoXuwqN A man light of flesh: (K:) a horse lean, lank, light of flesh, slender, or lank in the belly. (S.) ― -b2- mamoXuwqapN A damsel tall and slender: (K:) slender: or perfect in make, and goodly, or beautiful: (Msb:) or goodly, or beautiful, in stature. (S.)

2 tamoXiylN c
2. tamoXiylN: see tafoXiylN.

1 maXana AlOadiyma c
1. maXana AlOadiyma He pared, or removed the superficial part of, the hide. (TA in art. Adm.)

6 tamaAXana c
6. tamaAXana He wiped his hands together: see ZaribaAnN.

muwXaAnN c
muwXaAnN: see juracN.

timoXaMCN c
timoXaMCN: see tiboyaAnN, voce bayRana.

1 maXaI c
1. maXaI He walked, went, or went along; (MA, KL;) [in its primary sense] He went any pace upon his feet, afoot, or on foot; he footed; whether quickly or slowly: (Mgh, Msb:) he removed from place to place at pleasure: (Er-Rághib:) walked; went along, marched; travelled; trod; paced; stepped. See 5. ― -b2- maXaI also signifies He went on, or continued, in his course of action, &c. (Mughnee voce Oano, in explanation of this verb as used in Kur xxxviii. 5.) ― -b3- [maXaI (assumed tropical:) It (money) passed; was,
or became, current. ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) It (a calumny) was, or became, current. See miYobarN.] ― -b5- maXaI banoTuhu [His belly became moved, or in motion; it discharged itself.] (S, K, art. Tlq; &c.)

2 maXRaIa
2: see 4.

3 maAXaAhu c
3. maAXaAhu He walked, or went on foot, with him: he kept pace with him. See an ex. voce AlOaHoSRaAni.

4 OamoXaIa AldRawaMCu baTonahu c
4. OamoXaIa AldRawaMCu baTonahu (A, K, art. Hdr,) [The medicine moved, or purged, his bowels; made his belly to discharge itself:] and AlbaTona maXRaI↓. (TA, art. Tws, &c.)

5 tamaXRaI c
5. tamaXRaI i. q. maXaI: (TA:) [or, properly, and accord. to general usage, he walked with slow steps: so I have rendered it voce dalafa, &c.:] he walked heavily, with an effort. (TK voce tazaHRafa.) [One says in the present day, xarajotu OatamaXaI I went forth taking a walk; and tamaXRaI He walked; walked about.] ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] tamaXRato fiyhi HumayRaA AlkaOosi [The intoxicating influence of the cup of wine pervaded him, or] crept in him. (TA.) See also tafaXRaI.

6 tamaAXawoA c
6. tamaAXawoA They walked, or went on foot, one towards, or to, another. (TA.)

10 AisotamoXaI biAldRawaMCi c
10. AisotamoXaI biAldRawaMCi [He used the medicine as a laxative or purgative. (IbrD.)] (Az in L, art. Eqr.) ― -b2- AisotamoXaI bihi, referring to a plant, (K in art. SE,) He drank its water (i. e. infusion or the like) for moving the bowels. (TA ibid.)

maXRaMCN c
maXRaMCN [That goes with energy; a good or strong goer;] strong to walk, or go, or go on foot. (TA voce rijiylN.)

dawaMCu AlmaXiIRi c
dawaMCu AlmaXiIRi Medicine that moves, or purges, the bowels. (TA in art. Tws.)

maAXiyapN c
maAXiyapN A she-camel having numerous offspring. (S, Mgh.) ― -b2- Hence, and mawaAXK, as ominous of good, Camels, and cows, and sheep or goats that are for breeding and gain. (Mgh.)

mamoXaI c
mamoXaI A passage, or way, by a place; (TA;) [a walking-place: the gangway of a ship?]

4 OamoSaEato biwaladihaA c
4. OamoSaEato biwaladihaA She (a woman) brought forth, or cast forth, her child with a single moan, or hard breathing [or with a single throe;] like zakabato bihi. (IAar, L, art. Hfd.)

maSolN c
maSolN [A kind of AqT]: see kavNCN and EabiyvN.

muDogapN c
muDogapN A piece, or bit, of flesh (T, S, K), &c.: (T, K:) or a morsel, or gobbet, of flesh, i. e. a piece of flesh such as a man puts into his mouth: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, TA:) or as much as is chewed [at once]: (Msb:) and such as the heart, and the tongue, of a man: (TA:) and a fœtus when it has become like a lump of flesh: see Kur. xxii. 5; and see xaliyqN.

maDofN c
maDofN: see siyaraMCu.

1 maDaI c
1. maDaI and tamaDRaI↓ i. q. taqadRama [He advanced, proceeded, &c.]. (M.) ― -b2- maDaI He, or it, passed; passed away; went; or went away. (S, M, Msb, K.) ― -b3- [He went on.] ― -b4- maDaI lahu, said of time: see tasohiymN. ― -b5- [maDaI fiI sayorihi He advanced, or pressed onward, with a penetrative energy or force, or a sharpness and effectiveness, in his pace.] ― -b6- maDaIa AlOamoru, and Alqawolu, (assumed tropical:) The command, or order, and the saying, was effectual; had effect; was, or became, executed, or performed; syn. nafaca. (Msb, art nfc.) ― -b7- maDaI fiI AlOamori (assumed tropical:) He acted [or went on, and did so] with penetrative energy, or with sharpness, vigour, and effectiveness, in the affair; syn. nafaca. (S, M, K.) See maADK fiI AlOumuwri, below; and jasara. ― -b8- maDaI EalaI AlOamori He executed, performed, or accomplished, the affair; as also OamoDaAhu↓: (S:) and he kept, or applied himself, constantly, or perseveringly, to it. (Msb.) ― -b9- maDayotu ElI bayoEiI and OamoDayotuhu↓ I effected, or executed, my sale. (K.) ― -b10- maDaI It (a sword) cut; (M, K;) penetrated; was sharp.

4 OamoDaAhu c
4. OamoDaAhu [(assumed tropical:) He made it (i. e., a contract, sale, oath, &c.) to take effect; executed it; performed it.] ― -b2- OamoDaI AlOamora: see maDaI EalaI AlOamori. ― -b3- OamoDaI Alyamiyna He made the oath to be unconditional, without exception, absolutely or decisively or irreversibly binding. (TK voce jazama.) See jazama. ― -b4- OamoDaI Eahodahu (assumed tropical:) He made his covenant, or contract, or the like, to have, or take, effect; executed or performed it. (L, art. nfc.) ― -b5- OamoDaI raOoyFA He formed, or gave, a decided opinion. ― -b6- OamoDaI He signed a writing with his name, and so rendered it effective. ― -b7- See 1.

5 tamaDRaIa
5: see 1.

maADK fiI AlOumuwri c
maADK fiI AlOumuwri [(assumed tropical:) Penetrating, sharp, energetic, or acting with penetrative energy, or vigorous, and effective, in the performing of affairs: like XaHoXaHN, q. v. ― -b2- maADK is coupled with the epithets maAhirN and jaAdRN, &c., and implies penetration and skill, or proficiency in anything;] excelling, or surpassing, in doing, or performing, a thing: (KL from the “ Destoor ”:) [it is also coupled with jariIoCN and mutaqadRimN, in the T, art. jhr. See also naAficN, its syn.] ― -b3- OamorN maADK (assumed tropical:) A command, or an order, that is effectual; that has effect; that is executed, or performed; syn. naAficN. (L, art. nfc.) ― -b4- farasN maADK (assumed tropical:) A sharp, spirited, vigorous horse [&c.]; contr. of baliydN; (Lth, TA, voce nadobN;) exerting, or having, a penetrative energy, &c.: see maDI. ― -b5- kaAna celika fiI AlzRamani AlmaADiI That was in the time that is past; contr. of Almusotaqobal. (TA.)

timoDaMCN c
timoDaMCN One who performs affairs with energy and perseverance: an intensive epithet: see SamayaAnN.

5 tamaTRaqa c
5. tamaTRaqa He tasted repeatedly, or smacked his lips: see two explanations of this verb voce lamaZa.

1 maTalahu bidayonihi c
1. maTalahu bidayonihi, inf. n. maTolN, and maA Talahu↓, inf. n. maTaAlN, He delayed, or deferred, with him, or put him off, in the matter of his debt, by promising time after time to pay him. (Msb.) See daAfaEotuhu and sawRafahu.

3 maAoTala
3: see 1.

maTuwlN c
maTuwlN Much given to delaying, or deferring, with a creditor, or putting him off, in the matter of a debt, by promising time after time to pay him. (Msb.)

mamoTuwlN c
mamoTuwlN Iron, or a sword, (Az, TA,) beaten into a long shape: (Az, K:) or anything extended, elongated, or lengthened. (S.)

1 maTaA c
1. maTaA signifies He drew, or pulled, a thing; as, for instance, a well-rope: for] madRN and maTRN and maTowN are all one. (Az and TA in art. mT.) See an ex. from Zuheyr, voce vinaAyapN.

5 tamaTRaI c
5. tamaTRaI He stretched, in a neuter sense: as also tamaTRaTa and tamadRada.

muTaOLCu c
muTaOLCu [for muTawaMCu?] A stretching, through weariness, &c.? (TA, art. vOb.)

maTiyRapN c
maTiyRapN A camel: (Msb:) a camel, or beast, that one rides; a beast that goes with energy and
speed: (K:) or a she-camel, or he-camel, that is used for riding; (TA;) [and so a horse, &c.;] a saddle-camel, or camel that one rides. (KL.) ― -b2- See two exs. of a metaphorical meaning voce zaEama.

muTawaMCu c
muTawaMCu The stretching oneself by reason of fever. (As in TA, voce buraHaACu.) ― -b2- See vuwabaMCu.

maEa c
maEa [generally thus in all cases] is a word, or noun, (S, K,) or particle, (K,) denoting concomitance, (S, K,) &c. (K.) It is said to denote the commencement of concomitance, though this is not invariably the case. (MF and TA, voce fiI.) ― -b2- jiYotu maEa AlEaSori means Einoda AlEaSori. (Mughnee.)

8 AimotaEasa c
8. AimotaEasa: see Oalowava.

1 maEiSa c
1. maEiSa: see mugiSa.

1 maEuqa c
1. maEuqa: see Eamuqa.

4 maA OamoEaqahaA c
4. maA OamoEaqahaA: see Emq.

maEiyqN c
maEiyqN: see EamiyqN.

mutamaERaku Alfarasi c
mutamaERaku Alfarasi (T, art. rdI) or AlHimaAri (S, M, art. rdI) The horses' or asses' place of rolling upon the ground. See rdI.

maEolN c
maEolN [not maEilN] An agile, acute, clever, man: see XaEolN.

4 OamoEana c
4. OamoEana He (a horse) went far, (S, Msb, K,) in his run. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, OamoEana fiI AlTRalabi He went very far in search: (Msb:) or he went far, or to a great or an extraordinary length, therein. (Mgh.) ― -b3- AmEn fiI AlXRaIoCi, (Ham p. 817,) or fiI AlOamori, (MA, K, Har p. 176,) He went far, (K, Ham, Har,) or deep, or beyond bounds, (MA,) in, or into, the thing, or affair. (Ham, &c.) ― -b4- OamoEana liI biHaqRiI: see OacaEona.

AlmaEonu c
AlmaEonu The drawing of water.

miEFI c
miEFI A narrow, depressed place (See TaOoTaACN.) ― -b2- banaAtN miEFI The baEor. (T in art. bnI.) ― -b3- AlmiEaI Almusotaqiymu The rectum.

AlOamoEaACu c
AlOamoEaACu i. q. AlOaqoSaAbu; (AO: see voce qitobN;) the guts; i. e. bowels, or intestines, into which the food passes from the stomach: AlHaXaA is the name of all the places of the food; and in the belly are the OaEofaAj and the OaqotaAb, to which the food passes after the stomach, and these are the lower AmEAC; and all these are called the quSob: the HawaAyaA are all the AmEAC that wind, or take a coiled, or circular, form. (Zj, in his “ Khalk el-Insán. ”) ― -b2- OamoEaMCu: see a tropical signification (water-holes) of this pl. voce HawiyRapu.

maAqiTN c
maAqiTN A player with the ball. (O in art. SwE.) See SaAEN, last sentence.

3 maAqalahu c
3. maAqalahu, inf. n. mumaAqalapN He vied with him in diving: see gaAmasahu.

6 tamaAqalaA c
6. tamaAqalaA: see tagaATasaA.

muqolN c
muqolN The Theban palm; palma Thebaïca of Pococke; the cucifera of Theophrastes. ― -b2- Also The xuwS, or leaves, of the tree thus called: see nZm ― -b3- See also SamogN.

maqolahN c
maqolahN, for juroEapu maqolapK: see 3 in art. Sfn.

muqolapN c
muqolapN The ball, or globe, or bulb (lit. fat, XaHomap), of the eye, i. e., the eyeball, which comprises the white and the black. (Khalk el-Insán of Zj; and S, Msb, K.)

1 makara bihi c
1. makara bihi i. q. xadaEahu, (Msb, &c.,) see kaAdahu.

makorN c
makorN [Artifice; machination; stratagem; fraud; fraudulence; guile].

2 makRanahu c
2. makRanahu He gave him a place: (Jel, vi. 6:) he assigned him a place, and settled, or established, him. (Bd, ibid, where see more.) You say also, makRana lahu fiI manozilK [He assigned, or gave, him a place in an abode]. (S in art. bwO.) ― -b2- makRanahu mino XaIoCK, and Oamokanahu↓, He made him to have mastery, or dominion, or ascendancy, or authority, and power, over a thing; (Msb;) put it in his power. ― -b3- makRanahu mina AlXRaIoCi, and minohu Oamokana↓, He empowered him, enabled him, or rendered him able, to do the thing: he enabled him to have the thing within his power. Ex. yadayohi Oamokana↓ mino rukobatayohi He enabled his hands to take and grasp his knees. from a trad. (Mgh.)

4 Oamokanahu mino XaIoCi c
4. Oamokanahu mino XaIoCi He made him to have a thing within his power, or reach: enabled him to do, reach, get, or obtain, a thing. See 2. ― -b2- Oamokanahu It was within his power, or reach; was possible, or practicable, to him. ― -b3- Oamokanahu It became easy to him. (Msb.) It (an object of the chase) offered him an opportunity to shoot it or capture it; or became within his power, or reach. ― -b4- OamokiniI, said to a woman, [meaning Empower thou; i. e. grant thou access;] occurs in a poem. (S, art. ErD.) ― -b5- Oamokanatohu She granted him attainment.

5 tamakRana c
5. tamakRana i. q. AisotaqarRa: (Msb, art. qr:) it is very often used in this sense, as meaning He, or it, settled; became fixed, or established; it became fixed, or steady, in its place; when said of a man, particularly implying in authority and power: see qarRa. ― -b2- tamakRana mino XaIoCK, and Aisotamokana↓, He became possessed of mastery, or dominion, or ascendancy, or authority, and power, over a thing; he was able to avail himself of it: [he was, or became, within reach of him, or it.] (Msb.) ― -b3- tamakRana minohu He assumed authority over him.

10 Aisotamokana c
10. Aisotamokana: see 5. ― -b2- He, or it, was, or became, firm. It seems sometimes to mean It (a plant) took firm root.

mukonapN c
mukonapN, (Msb, TA,) with damm, (TA,) Power; (Msb, * TA;) ability; (TA;) strength. (Msb.)

makinapN c
makinapN i. q. tamakRunu. (Sh, TA.) ― -b2- AlnRaAsu EalaI makinaAtihimo means ElI maqaArRihimo. (IAar, TA.)

makRaAnu c
makRaAnu: see maSRaAnN in art. mS.

makonaAnN c
makonaAnN: see rayRiHapN.

makaAnapN c
makaAnapN Greatness, and high rank or standing. in the estimation of the Sultán: (Msb:) an honourable place in the estimation of a king. (K.)

jalasa mutamakRinFA c
jalasa mutamakRinFA He sat in a firm, or settled, posture; as when one sits cross-legged.

mukRaMCN c
mukRaMCN The bird so called, because of its colour: see Oaxoraju.

1 malRahu c
1. malRahu He put it (namely bread, or flesh-meat,) into hot ashes, [to bake, or roast]. (K, &c.) ― -b2- malRa AlvRawoba He sewed, or tacked, the garment, or piece of cloth, [slightly,] previously to the [stronger] sewing termed AlkafR. (S.) See also XalRa. ― -b3- malilotuhu, & malilotu Eanohu, I was avers from it; (T;) loathed it; was disgusted by it, with it, or at it; (T, S, K;) [was weary of it;] turned
away from it with disgust. (T.) See saYima. ― -b4- malRa malAaluka [May thy disgust pass away, or cease]: see OaDalRa QllRehu DalaAlaka.

4 Oamolalotu c
4. Oamolalotu & Oamolayotu: see 4 in art. HZ. ― -b2- OamalRa: see an ex. voce OadalRa.

8 AimotalRa milRatahu c
8. AimotalRa milRatahu He follows his way of religion: see 8 in art. XrE.

malRapN c
malRapN The hollow that is made for baking bread: or the hot dust and ashes [in which the bread is baked]. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hot ashes: (S, K:) ashes, and earth, in which fire is kindled. (TA, art. xbz.) ― -b3- xubozu malRapK Bread baked in hot ashes. (S.) [It is generally made in the form of thick round cakes.]

milRapN c
milRapN A religion; (S, Msb, K;) a way of belief and practice in respect of religion. (T, &c.) ― -b2- See 8.

maluwlN c
maluwlN Conceiving [frequent] disgust. (Msb.) See cawRaAqN.

malAalN c
malAalN: see 1.

maliylN c
maliylN A man burned by the sun; as also mamoluwlN↓. (TA.) See an ex. in a verse cited voce OaSoramu; and see TulomahN.

mamoluwlN c
mamoluwlN Flesh-meat covered over in live coals. (TA, art. ErD.) ― -b2- See maliylN.

mulomuwlN c
mulomuwlN An iron style with which one writes on tablets. (K.) ― -b2- The style, or bodkin, with which collyrium is applied to the eyes. (S, K.) In the CK, incorrectly, malomuwlN: the former is found in MS. copies of the K, as well as in the S, and is right accord. to the TK.

maliyEN c
maliyEN: see gumoluwlN.

1 malaqahu c
1. malaqahu He flayed him with a whip: like salaqahu. (TA in art. slq.)

5 tamalRaqahu c
5. tamalRaqahu, (S, K,) and tamalRaqa lahu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tamalRuqN and timilRaAqN, [like tiHimRaAlN and tikilRaAmN, not tamolaAqN as in the CK,] He behaved in a loving, or an affectionate, and a blandishing, or coaxing, manner to him. (S, Msb, * K.) See a verse cited in art. rDw, conj. 5.

malaqiyRapN c
malaqiyRapN [A swiftly-running mare]. See EabRara bihi. malRaAqN Vehement in journeying, or in his pace; i. q. malRaAxN. (TA, voce malRaAxN.)

mimolaqapN c
mimolaqapN A harrow: see malRasa.

1 malakahu c
1. malakahu He possessed it, or owned it, [and particularly] with ability to have it to himself exclusively: (M, K:) [and he exercised, or had, authority over it; for] mulokN signifies the exercise of authority to command and to forbid in respect of the generality of a people [&c.]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the having possession and command or authority: and the having power to exercise command or authority. (TA.) milokN, as inf. n. of malakahu meaning He possessed it, is more common than malokN and mulokN. ― -b2- [malaka Oamorahu He had the ruling, or ordering, of his affair, or case] And malaka EalaI AlnRaAsi Oamorahumo He had the dominion, or sovereignty, or ruling power, over the people. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- See 4.

2 malRakahu c
2. malRakahu He made him to possess a thing; (S, K;) as also Oamolakahu↓. (K.) ― -b2- He made him king; or made him to have dominion, kingship, or rule. (Msb, K.) ― -b3- yumalRaka AlrRajulu Oamorahu [The man shall be made to have the ruling, or ordering, of his affair, or affairs, or case]. (Sh, T in art. dyn.)

3 maAlka OumRahu c
3. maAlka OumRahu: see Xadana.

4 AlEajiyna c
4. AlEajiyna malaka↓ and Oamolakahu He kneaded well the dough. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See 2.

5 tamalRaka c
5. tamalRaka He took possession of a thing [absolutely or] by force. (Msb.)

6 maA tamaAlaka Oano faEala c
6. maA tamaAlaka Oano faEala He could not restrain himself from doing; (Mgh, Msb;) syn. maA tamaAsaka [q. v.] (S.)

milokN c
milokN: its pl. OamolAakN, in common conventional language means [or rather includes] Houses and lands. (TA.) See its pl. pl. OamolAakaAtN.

mulokN c
mulokN Dominion; sovereignty; kingship; rule; mastership; ownership; possession; right of possession; authority; sway. ― -b2- muloku QllRehi God's world of spirits; or invisible world. (TA, art. Xhd.) ― -b3- [mulokN (when distinguished from mlkwt) The dominion that is apparent; as that of the earth.]

malakN c
malakN An angel: see maOolakN. ― -b2- malakN Water. (S.)

maliku AlOamolAaki c
maliku AlOamolAaki The king of kings. See OaxonaEu.

malAaku AlOamori c
malAaku AlOamori and milAakuhu↓ That whereby the thing &c. subsists: (S, KL:) its qaiwaAm [q. v.] by whom, or by which, it is ruled, or ordered: (K:) its foundation; syn. OaSoluhu: (KL:) its support; that upon which it rests: (T, TA:) it may be rendered the cause, or means, of the subsistence of the thing; &c.

milaAkN c
milaAkN see malAakN.

maAlikN c
maAlikN: see rabRN. ― -b2- maAliku AlOamori The possessor of command, or rule. ― -b3- AlmaAliku Alkabiyru The Great Master, or Owner; i. e., God; in contradistinction to AlmaAliku AlSRagiyru the little master, or owner; i. e., the human owner of a slave, &c. ― -b4- maAlikN AlHaziynu: (so in one copy of the S: in another, and the MA, and Kzw, maAliku AlHaziyni:) [The heron: or a species thereof] in Pers. bwtymAr; (MA;) a certain bird, long in the neck and legs, called in Pers. bwtymAr. (Kzw:) see sabayoTarN ― -b5- Oabuw maAlikK Hunger. (MF, art. jbr.) See also OabN.

OamolaAkaAtN c
OamolaAkaAtN pl. of OamolAakN pl. of milokN Goods, or chattels, of a bride: see OagonaMCN in art. gnI.

malakapN c
malakapN [A faculty.] A quality firmly rooted in the mind. (KT.)

malakuwtu AllRehi c
malakuwtu AllRehi God's world of corporeal beings. (TA, art. Xhd.) Generally The kingdom of God.

miliyk c
miliyk is also syn. with mamoluwkN; this is meant in the TA where it is said that mulakaMCu in the saying labaA muluwkN walayosa labaA mulakaMCu [We have kings of bees, but we have not slaves] is pl. of Almaliyku from Almamoluwku: it is also said in art. rgw in the TA, (see 4 in that art.) that maliykapN is syn. with mamoluwkapN.

Oamolaku c
Oamolaku: see XaroTN. and also OamolaOu, and OarabN. ― -b2- maA Oamoliku XadRFA walAa UiroxaMCF: see XadRa.

mamolakapN c
mamolakapN A kingdom, or realm. (S.)

mamoluwkN c
mamoluwkN A slave; a bondman; syn. EabodN, (S,) or raqiyqN. (TA.) In the present day, specially, A white male slave. (TA.) See marobuwbN.

1 mulRiIa OabAahu c
1. mulRiIa OabAahu: see labisa OabaAhu in art. lbs. ― -b2- mulRiytu fulAabFA I was made to live long with such a one. (Ham, p. 412.) ― -b3- malRaAka QllRehu Habiybaka May God make thee to have enjoyment of thy friend (matRaEaka bihi) and to live long with him. (S.) See labisa.

4 Oamolayotu c and Oamolalotu
4. Oamolayotu Oamolalotu: see 4 in art. HZ.

5 tamalRaI AlEayoXa c
5. tamalRaI AlEayoXa He lived long. (T.) ― -b2- tamalRaI bXaIoCK He enjoyed a thing. ― -b3- tamalRayotu Eumorahu: see a verse of Ibn-Ahmar cited voce OabolaI in art. blw.

maliyRFA c
maliyRFA A while: (Msb:) or a long time. (S, Msb.)

1 manRa Ealayohi c
1. manRa Ealayohi, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
manuna
, (Msb,) inf. n. manRN (S, M, Msb, K) and minRiynaI; (K;) and AmtnR↓; (Msb;) He conferred, or bestowed, upon him, a favour, or benefit. (S, M, Msb, K.) You say, manRa Ealayohi XayoOF, and biXaIoCK, which latter is more common, and Elyh bihi AmtnR↓ He conferred, or bestowed, a thing upon him as a favour. (Msb.) ― -b2- manRa Ealayohi, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. manRN (T, Msb) or minRapN; (S, K;) and Amtn↓ (S, M, Msb, K) and tmnRn↓; (M;) He reproached him for a favour, or benefit, which he (the former) had conferred, or bestowed; (M;) he recounted his gifts or actions to him. (Msb.) Ex., EalayohaA bimaA maharahaA AimotanRa↓ [He reproached her for the dowry he had given her]. (K, art. mhr.) See Bd, ii. 264. See also an ex. in a verse cited voce sarifa.

5 tamanRaRa
5: see 1.

8 Uimotanana
8: see 1.

mano c
mano [used for maA in the sense of What? as in the following of El-Khansà,
OalaA mano liEayoniI laA tajifRu dumuwEuhaA
O! what aileth mine eye, that its tears dry not? quoted in the TA, art. fvO.] ― -b2- mano: respecting its dual manaAno and manayono, and its pl. manuwno and maniyno, see I'Ak, p. 319. ― -b3- mano liI bikacaA: see bi (near the end of the paragraph).

mino c
mino: ― -b2- zayodN OaEoqalu mino Oano yakocib means mina AlcRaiI yakocibu (Kull, p. 78) [i. e. Zeyd is more reasonable than he who lies: but, though this is the virtual meaning, the proper explanation, accord. to modern usage, is, that Oano is here for OanRa with the adjunct pronoun hu; for in a phrase of this kind, an adjunct pronoun is sometimes expressed; so that the aor. must be marfooa; and the literal meaning is, Zeyd is more reasonable than that he will lie; which is equivalent to saying, Zeyd is too reasonable to lie. It may be doubted, however, whether a phrase of this kind be of classical authority. The only other instance that I have found is huwa OaHoSanu mino Oano yoraAm waOaEazRu min Oano yuDaAm, in the TA, voce Oalo. Accord. to modern usage, one may say, Oanota OaEoqalu mino OanRaka tafoEalu kacaA, which virtually means Thou art too reasonable to do such a thing; and here we cannot substitute QlRacin for OanR. See Oano for OanRa.] ― -b3- OaxozaI QllRehu AlkaAciba minRiI waminoka: see OaIRN ― -b4- laqiytu minohu OasadFA: see OasodN: and laqiytu ― -b5- minohu baHorFA; and raOayotu minohu baHorFA: see bHr ― -b6- mino in the sense of Einoda: see jadRN ― -b7- jaraI minohu majoraI kacaA: see 1 in art. jrI ― -b8- mino and Eano, differences between: see Eano ― -b9- mino often means Some. ― -b10- Often redundant: see 1 in art. EyD. ― -b11- Of, or among: see two exs. voce fiI, latter part. ― -b12- HusayonN minRiI waOanaA minohu Hoseyn and I are as one thing, [as though each were a part of the other,] in respect of the love that is due to us, &c. (Commencement of a tradition in the Jámi' es-Sagheer: thus explained in the Expos. of El-Munáwee.) See Ham, p. 139; and De Sacy's Gr. i. 492. ― -b13- maA OanaA mano dadK walaA AldRadu minRiI: see art. dd. IbrD confirms my rendering of this saying. ― -b14- yataEarRaDu UilaI XaIoCK layosa minohu [He applies himself to a thing not of his business to do]. (TA, art. EX.) ― -b15- layosa minRaA He is not of our dispositions, nor of our way, course, or manner, of acting, or the like. (TA, art. gX.) ― -b16- layosa minRiI (Kur, ii. 250) He is not of my followers: (Bd, Jel:) or he is not at one, or in union, with me. (Bd. See 1 in art. TEm.) See a similar usage of mn, voce EiySN. ― -b17- OanaA minohu kaHaAqini AlUihaAlapi: see HaAqinN ― -b18- mino is used in the sense of fI in the phrase mino yawomi AljumoEapi [In, or on, the day of congregation] in the Kur lxii. 9. (K, Jel.) So, too, in mino yawomihi In, or on, his, meaning, the same, day: and mino saAEatihi In, or at, his, meaning the same, instant of time. See also De Sacy's Gr., ii. 526.

muna QllRehi c
muna QllRehi is for Oayomunu AllReh.

maniIRN c
maniIRN and AlmaniIRu, from mano: see OayRiIRN; and De Sacy's Anthol. Gr. Ar., pp. 374 and 401, and ???.

manRN c
manRN: see riTolN.

minRapN c
minRapN [An obligation, EalaI OaHadK upon one, and also lahu to him.] ― -b2- A favour, or benefit, conferred, or bestowed. (M, Msb.) ― -b3- Also an inf. n. See manRa Ealayohi.

laA OafoEaluhu OuxoraI Almanuwni c
laA OafoEaluhu OuxoraI Almanuwni I will not do it till the end of time. (S.) ― -b2- manuwnN is fem. and sing. and pl. (Fr, S.)

maniynN c
maniynN The first (or main) rope of a well. See karabN.

manRaAnN c
manRaAnN Very bountiful or beneficent. ― -b2- Also [Very reproachful for his gifts;] one who gives nothing without reproaching for it and making account of it: an intensive epithet. (TA.)

AimotinaAniIRN c
AimotinaAniIRN Gratuitous; granted as a favour: opposed to wujuwbiIRN.

manojanuwqN mnjnwq
manojanuwqN, manojanuwnN, mionajunwqN, minojanuwnN, and manojaniyqN: see art. jnq.

1 manaEa c
1. manaEa He prevented, hindered, held back, [impeded, withheld, arrested, restrained, kept, debarred, precluded, inhibited, forbade, prohibited, interdicted:] (MA, KL, &c.:) he denied, or refused; doubly trans.; (S, K, &c.:) manoEN is the contr. of UiEoTaMCN. (S, Mgh, K.) ― -b2- manaEahu [He protected it, or defended it, or guarded it, (namely a place or the like) from, or against, encroachment, invasion, or attack:] he protected, defended, or guarded, him. (T in art. cb.) ― -b3- manaEahu AlEaTiyRapu [He refused him the gift]. (TA in art. Hrm.) ― -b4- manaEahu AlXRaIoCa i. q. Haramahu UiyRaAhu [q. v.] (S in art. Hrm.) ― -b5- manuEa AlXRaIoCu, inf. n. manaAEapN, i. q. AiEotazRa and taEasRara. (TA.) See 8. ― -b6- maA manaEaka OalRaA tasojuda (Kur vii. 11): see OabaI.

3 maAnaEahu AlXRaIoCa c
3. maAnaEahu AlXRaIoCa He disputed, or contested, with him the thing: (Msb:) he refused him the thing: (TK:) he endeavoured, or contended with him, to make him, or to entice him, to abstain from, or relinquish, the thing; (TA;) [he endeavoured to turn him away from the thing; to prevent his obtaining it or doing it; he prevented him from obtaining or doing the thing, being also prevented by him; i. e. he reciprocally prevented him, &c.: and hence the meaning in the TA; and then that in the Msb:] maAnaEuwA EaduwRahumo signifies i. q. HaAjazuwhumo: (TK, art. Hjz:) see the latter. ― -b2- tamanRaEa EalaI AlsRanapi [he resisted, or withstood, the year of dearth]: said of an animal. (K.)

5 tamanRaEa mina AlXRaIoCi biqRawomihi c
5. tamanRaEa mina AlXRaIoCi biqRawomihi and AimotanaEa↓ He became strengthened, or fortified, against the thing by his people, or party; syn. taqawRaI. (Msb.) ― -b2- tamanRaEa Eanohu He refrained, forbore, or abstained, from it, as being forbidden, or prohibited. (K, * TA.) See 8. ― -b3- tamanRaEa bihi and bihi AimtnE↓ he protected, or defended, himself by it, namely a fortress; syn. AiHotamaI. (TA.)

6 tamaAnaEaA c
6. tamaAnaEaA i. q. taHaAjazaA: (K, art. Hjz:) see the latter.

8 AimotanaEa c
8. AimotanaEa [It was, or became, prevented from being; it necessarily was not. You say yamotaniEu hecaA liwujuwdi caAka This is prevented from being, or may not be, or necessarily is not, because of that's being. And yamotaniEu Oano takuwan hecaA This may not be.] ― -b2- AimotanaEa He refrained, forbore, abstained, or held back, (Msb, K,) mina AlOamori from the thing. or affair; (Msb;) as also Eanohu tamanRaEa↓: (TA:) he did so voluntarily, of his own free will or choice: he refused: you say, AimotnaEa Eanohu he refrained, &c., from it voluntarily, &c.; refused it; or refused to do it. (MF. in art. HSr.) See OabaI. ― -b3- AimotanaEa Ealayohi He, or it, opposed him; resisted him; withstood him; repugned him; was incompliant, or
unyielding, to him; see OabaI Ealayohi. ― -b4- AimotanaEa It was, or became, inaccessible, or inapproachable; like manuEa↓; syn. with HaSuna, q. v.: and also, difficult of access, as in an instance in art. ObI (last sentence of 4); and also Earisa EalaIRa. ― -b5- See 5.

mianoEapN c
mianoEapN: see manaEapN.

manaEapN c
manaEapN State, and power, of resistance; lit. a state of might of one's people or party, so that such as desires to do so will not prevail against him: [or a state of might in his people or party, &c.; or a state of might, and power of resistance, in his people or party:] (Msb:) [resistibility: or simply resistance:] inaccessibleness, or unapproachableness, of a people; as also manoEapN↓ and minoEapN↓. (TA.)

manuwEN c
manuwEN One who denies, or refuses to give; as also maAniEN↓ and manRaAEN↓. (K.)

maniyEN c
maniyEN, from manuEa, [Unapproachable; inaccessible:] difficult of access; fortified; strong: (TK, voce wazarN:) [defended, or protected, against attack: like HaSiynN: resistive; resisting attack;] applied to a fortress. (Msb.) ― -b2- qawomN munaEaMCu [pl. of maniyEN] An inaccessible, or unapproachable, people. (TA.)

manRaAEN c
manRaAEN manuwEN.

maAniEN c
maAniEN manuwEN.

AlmutamanRiEaAni c
AlmutamanRiEaAni The young she-camel and young she-kid: because they resist the year of dearth by reason of their youthful vigour, &c. (K.)

1 manaAhu c
1. manaAhu He tried him; proved him. (S, K.) You say, manaAhu AllRehu biHubRihaA God tried him by love of her. (T.) And muniIa bikacaA He was tried by such a thing. (T.) ― -b2- manaI He meditated [a thing in his mind]; syn. qadRara. (Bd, ii. 73.) See OaminoyRapN.

5 tamanRaAhu c
5. tamanRaAhu He wished, or desired, it. (K, TA.) ― -b2- AltRamanRiI relates to that which is possible and to that which is impossible: whereas AltRarajRiI relates only to what is possible. (I'Ak, p. 90.)

10 tusomanonaI c
10. tusomanonaI, said of a she-camel: see 8 in art. smw.

manFI c
manFI see maniyRapN.

munoyapN c
munoyapN A thing wished for by a man: pl. munFI. (T.) This word and OumoniyRapN↓ signify the same. (M, Mgh, Msb, K.) See an ex. in a verse cited voce Oawo ― -b2- Almunoyapu in the case of a covered she-camel, The period by the end of which one knows whether she be pregnant or not. (M.) ― -b3- munoyapN of a mare, Twenty days. (M, voce safuwdN.)

maniyRapN c
maniyRapN [A decreed event. Fate; destiny:] The decree of death: (IB:) or the decreed term [of life, or] of a living being: (Er-Rághib:) death; (S, M, K;) because it is decreed; (S, M;) as also manFI↓: (M, K:) [properly a thing decreed: and hence the pl.] AlmanaAyaA signifies the fates or decrees [of God]. (T.) ― -b2- maniyRapN also means (assumed tropical:) A man of courage upon his saddle: (TA in art. HwI:) pl. manaAyaA: see an ex. voce HawiyRapN.

OumoniyRapN c
OumoniyRapN An object of wish, or desire: originally, a thing that a man meditates (yuqadRiruhu) in his mind; from manaI signifying qadRara: and hence applied to a lie; and to what is wished, or desired, and what is read, or desired [pl. OamaAniIRu and OamaAnK]. (Bd in ii. 73.) See munobapN and HajowaI.

layosa bihi mahaAhN c
layosa bihi mahaAhN, (T in art. rmd,) or fiyhi, (L in that art.,) It has no goodness and lastingness. (T and L in that art.)

4 Oamohadato biwaladihaA c
4. Oamohadato biwaladihaA She (a woman) brought forth, or cast forth, her child with a single impulse. (IAar, in L, art. xfd.) ― -b2- Oamohadato biAlwaladi is syn. with Oasohadato bihi; (IAar, O, TA in art. shd;) and zakabot bihi, &c. (IAar, L, in art. xfd.)

4 Oamohalahu c
4. Oamohalahu He acted gently, softly, or in a leisurely manner, towards, or with, him. (K.) He granted him some delay, or respite; let him alone, or left him, for a while. (S, K.) [In both senses] i. q. Oarowadahu. (S, art. rwd.) You say OamohiloniI HatRaI OafoEal kacaA Grant thou me some delay that I may do such a thing; give me time to do such a thing. See Har p. 164.

5 tamahRala c
5. tamahRala He acted, or behaved, deliberately, or leisurely; without haste; (S, Msb, K;) in an affair. (S, Msb.)

maholN c
maholN and mahalN↓ and muholapN↓ Gentleness; a leisurely manner of acting or proceeding. (Msb, K, &c.) ― -b2- maholaFA Act gently, softly, or leisurely.

mahalN c
mahalN: see maholN.

muholapN c
muholapN: see maholN. ― -b2- fiI AlOamori muholapN In the affair is a delay; syn. taOoxiyrN. (Msb.) ― -b3- fiI muholapK Leisurely; gently; by little and little.

guromuwlN mutomahilRN c
guromuwlN mutomahilRN A hard penis: see qaAsibN.

mahomapN c
mahomapN A far-extending mafaAzap [or desert, &c.]. (S, K.) See UiSomit.

8 Aimotahanahu c
8. Aimotahanahu He used it for service and work: (K:) i. q. Aibotacalahu, q. v.: (S, Msb:) He held it in mean estimation. (Har, p. 65.)

miahonapN c
miahonapN [is syn. with EamalN and fiEolN, and means work, labour, or] service; ministration; performance of an office. (S, &c.) ― -b2- Also, The clothes worn in service, or in the performance of business. (Msb.)

mahiynN c
mahiynN Contemptible; abject: (S, K) weak: having little judgment and discrimination. (K.)

mahowN c
mahowN, applied to a sword, Thin edged: see an ex. voce xaXiybapN. ― -b2- saloHN mahowN Thin excrement. (Skr in Carm. Huds. p. 15.)

mahFA c
mahFA (assumed tropical:) Front teeth (vagorN) that are clean, white, and lustrous (having much mMC): so in a verse of El-Aashà [cited voce rafRa]. (TA.)

mumahRaI c
mumahRaI Beverage, or wine, (XaraAb,) mixed with much water. (IAar, in TA, art. Hnc.)

mMCN c
mMCN Water. ― -b2- maMCu AlZRahori [The seminal fluid]. (K, voce AinobatRa.) See Kur, lxxxvi. 6, 7, and see 4 in art. rwq. ― -b3- maMCN Lustre [likened to water, and running water,] of the teeth, (IbrD,) &c.: see ZalomN and darozN and garobN. ― -b4- maMCN The water of a sword: see firinodN and rawonaqN: also its lustre. ― -b5- sayofN kaviyru AlmaMCi [A sword much diversified with wavy marks or streaks in its grain; as are the swords of Damascus &c.] (TA voce UiboriyqN.) ― -b6- banaAtu AlmaMCi i. q. AlgaraAniyqu. [storks or cranes]. (L, art. wDr.) See EirosN. ― -b7- Aibonu AlmaMCi is (tropical:) A kind of bird; pl. banaAtu AlmaMCi; (Mgh in art. bnI:) the aquatic bird; the bird of the water. (Msb in art. bnw.) ― -b8- maMCu AlXRabaAbi: see XabaAbN. ― -b9- maMCu Alwajohi: see Haqana and taXahRala. ― -b10- maMCu AlcRahabi Gold-wash for gilding: and maMCu AlfiDRapi Silverwash for silvering: you say, TalaAhu bimaMCi AlcRahabi, and AlfiDRapi He washed it over with gold, and silver. ― -b11- maMCN is used as a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is maACapN; and therefore is sometimes made, as a pl., to have a pl. epithet: ex. maACN EicaAbN. (See EacobN). maMCapN signifies A water; or some water.

mwqN c
mwqN [Stupidity;] foolishness with lack of understanding. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- A kind of boot: see juromuwqN.

5 tamawRala c
5. tamawRala He became abundant in wealth. (TA, art. vmr).

maAlN c
maAlN Whatever one possesses: (K:) property; wealth:] accord. to Mohammad [the Hanafee Imám), whatever men possess, of dirhems, or deenárs, or gold, or silver, or wheat, or barley, or bread, or beasts, or garments or pieces of cloth, or weapons, or other things: (Mgh:) [property, or wealth:] or originally what one possesses of gold and silver: then applied to anything that one acquires and possesses of substantial things: and mostly applied by the Arabs to camels, because these constitute most of their wealth: (IAth, TA:) and animals. (TA.) ― -b2- maAlN Camels or sheep or goats. (S.) The mAl of the people of the desert consists of what are termed naEamN, (T, Msb,) i. e. Cattle, consisting of camels or neat or sheep or goats, or all these, or camels alone; (Msb in art. nEm;) herds, or flocks, or herds and flocks. ― -b3- maAlN A square in arithmetic: pl. OamowaAlN. See jacorN. ― -b4- rajulN maAlN, for cuwmaAlK. (L, art. Syd.)

maAliIRN c
maAliIRN Of, or relating to, property or wealth.

muwmN c
muwmN [Pleurisy]: see birosaAmN and HumaAmN.

mawaAmiI c
mawaAmiI Lands wherein is nothing: see balRuwqapN.

2 mawRaha c
2. mawRaha He silvered or gilded, (S, K,) or washed over with gold or silver, (Msb,) a thing (S, Msb, K, TA) of brass (TA) or copper or iron. (S, K.) ― -b2- He [varnished or] embellished falsehood so as to give it the appearance of truth. (TA.) He falsified information, Ealayohi to him, in reply to a question. (K.) ― -b3- He involved in confusion, or doubt; or practised concealment or disguise: or he concealed or disguised: (S, TA:) and he deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted. (TA.) ― -b4- He varnished, or embellished with a false colouring.

4 OamaAha c
4. OamaAha He (a digger) produced, or fetched out, water, by his labour or work; syn. OanobaTa AlmaMCa: (S, K:) or reached the water: (Msb:) or reached much water; as also OamohaI. (AA, in TA, art. nbT.) ― -b2- OamaAhu AlrRakiyRapa He (a man) produced, or fetched out, by his labour, or work [in digging,] the water of the well; syn. OanobaTa maMCahaA: (S, K:) He (God) made the water of the well to be much, or abundant. (Msb.)

maAhapN c
maAhapN Small-pox: see MhapN in art. Awh.

maAwiyRapN mAwyh mAwyp mAYy mAYyp
maAwiyRapN A mirror; so called in relation to water, because of its clearness, and because images are seen in it as they are in clear water: the m is a radical letter. (T in art. AwI.)

AlmayosaAnu c
AlmayosaAnu One of the two stars called AlhanoEapu. The other [ ξ] is called AlzRirRu. (El-Kazweenee.)

1 maAXa c
1. maAXa He mixed hair with wool: see Taraqa; and see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 28. ― -b2- maAXa AlkalAama i. q. TaAraqaha [He practised various modes of speech]. (TA in art. Trq.)

4 AmAEhu c
4. AmAEhu He made it to flow. (Msb.)

7 AnmAE c
7. AnmAE It flowed. (Msb.)

maAYiEN c
maAYiEN Anything in a melted state, fluid, or liquid: opposed to jaAmidN. (Msb.)

mayoEapN c
mayoEapN Briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (S.) The prime, or first part, of youth, and of the day. (S, K.) The first part of the run of a horse: (S:) the first part, and the briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, of a run, and of intoxication: or the main part of anything. (TA.) ― -b2- And The flowing of anything poured out. (TA.)

1 maAla c
1. maAla [He, or it, inclined, leant, bent, propended, tended, declined, deviated, or deflected.] ― -b2- maAla maEahu and maAyalahu↓ He conformed with, and assisted, or aided, him. (TA.) ― -b3- maAla Uilayohi He loved him. (TA.) ― -b4- He wronged him. (TA.) He was, or became, inimical to him. ― -b5- maAlati AldRaAbRapu mino rijolihaA (K, art. gmz,) i. q. ZalaEato [It limped]. (TA.)

2 mayRala bayona XayoYayoni c
2. mayRala bayona XayoYayoni He wavered, or vacillated, between two things. (S, MA.) See 10.

3 maAyalahu c
3. maAyalahu He inclined towards him reciprocally: and maAyalaA they two inclined each towards the other. (TK, art. hwd.) See also maAla maEahu in 1.

5 tamayRala
5: See 6. ― -b2- tamayRala biAlqawoli He vacillated in the saying: see tarajRaHa.

6 tamaAyala fiI miXoyatihi c
6. tamaAyala fiI miXoyatihi [He affected an inclining of his body, or a bending, or he inclined his body, or bent, from side to side, in his gait; a meaning well known, and still common]; (S;) syn. tavanRaI. (Har, p. 269.) ― -b2- See tazaAyugN. ― -b3- tamaAyalato fiI miXoyatihaA and tamayRalato↓ signify the same. (TA.) ― -b4- tamaAyala UilaI AlXRaIoCi; and Eano Tariyqihi: i. q. tajaAnafa [He affected a deviation, or purposely deviated from his course, &c.] (TA in art. jnf.)

10 AstmAlhu c
10. AstmAlhu, and AstmAl biqalobihi, (S, K,) He inclined him, and his heart. (K.) ― -b2- AisotamaAlahu He attracted him to himself; or sought to make him incline. (MA.) ― -b3- AstmAl is a quasi-pass. of mayRalahu↓. (K, * TA.)

miylN c
miylN as used by the Arabs, [A mile:] The distance to which the eye reaches along land: accord. to the ancient astronomers, three thousand cubits: accord to the moderns, four thousand cubits: but the difference is merely verbal; for they agree that its extent is ninety-six thousand digits; [about 5166 English feet;] each digit being the measure of six barley-corns, each placed with its belly next to another; but the ancients say that the cubit is thirty-two digits; which makes the mile three thousand cubits. (Msb, which see for more.) See also muTolibN ― -b2- myilN i. q. mulomuwlN, [A style]. (K.)

mayalN c
mayalN A natural wryness. (S.)

miylaAni c
miylaAni (?) of a maHaAlap of a well: see vinaAyapN.

mayRaAlN c
mayRaAlN [i. q. mutamaAyilN, Inclining much]. (A, art. fyd.) See sayRaAlN.

Oamoyalu c
Oamoyalu Swaying on horseback: see an ex. of its pl. miylN in a verse cited voce OaXoEala. ― -b2- EimRapN mayolaMCu: see qafodaMCu.

AmAlpu AlOalifi c
AmAlpu AlOalifi The inclining of the sound of A when quiescent, after fet-hah, towards the sound of I; so that the fet-hah, with that A, composes a sound the same as that of the long “ e ” in the English word “ there. ” This is accordant with present usage; and I have not found any learned Arab who asserts otherwise. See also naAbN, and HajRaAjN, and maXuwbN.
